Award.AwardTitle: INTEROP--Spatial Ontology Community of Practice: an Interdisciplinary Network to Support Geospatial Data Sharing, Integration, and Interoperability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Award: 0955816
PI: Nancy Weigand
Project Title: Spatial Ontology Community of Practice: an Interdisciplinary Network to Support Geospatial Data Sharing, Integration and Interoperability (INTEROP)


Geospatial data, which describe location information for geographic features, are pervasive across many disciplines and fundamental for diverse applications, such as economic development, natural resources, environmental protection, and emergency response. But, re-using geospatial data remains difficult because of the heterogeneity. Although progress has been made by initiatives such as the National Spatial Data Infrastructure (NSDI) and Geospatial One-Stop to distribute data, it is now necessary to address issues of standards harmonization and agreement on the meanings of relevant concepts from diverse data sets due to the use of different community views. Semantic interoperability has been recognized as a stumbling block to collaboration needed by research communities. As a solution, well designed, formal ontologies, relying on agreements between communities on unambiguous representation of concepts and relationships for a given problem area, can be used as an analytic tool to bridge community gaps. Unfortunately, many communities lack the expertise to develop, test, and disseminate such ontologies on their own, and, further, common ontologies require agreement across a range of communities. The purpose of this Network is to create such opportunities for the geospatial community and extend the results to related communities. The Network can be considered as an umbrella over other more specific domains linked through the Network. The Network is based on an existing Spatial Ontology Community of Practice (SOCoP) network that already has a core group of active participants from academia, government, and industry.

Mechanisms for the Network include an on-line collaboration environment, a repository for geospatial ontologies with tools; educational and participatory workshops for a broad geospatial community to solicit input on use cases, smaller working group sessions on one or two chosen domains to collaborate on developing ontologies that work across use cases, and interactions with standards groups for formal publishing of ontologies, demonstrations, and research activities. The SOCoP INTEROP network will also provide training and outreach in cross-area standards, data-sharing, and information management in scientific and local communities by demonstrating the power of cooperative modeling of semantics. An educational component on geospatial ontologies will also be developed. The project will contribute to a model to incorporate semantics into the next phase of the National Spatial Data Infrastructure

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to provide mechanisms for semantic interoperability of geospatial data, that is, being able to integrate or query information across geospatial data sets based on meaning. Geospatial data refer to data that have a geographic or locational component. This includes features or objects on, above, or below the earth’s surface that have spatial information tied to them, such as coordinates, address, city, or place name. Example data sets include soils, roads, rivers, parcels, administrative units, etc. Semantic problems occur when similar kinds of geospatial data are generated by different jurisdictions that use diverse concepts and terms. For example, many countries use a different classification system for land cover, while cities and counties often have different land use coding systems. This makes it difficult to pose regional queries to find areas with the same type of land use or land cover. A proposed solution is to disambiguate and relate terms through ontologies, which are knowledge bases that describe a domain. Ontologies employ a formal representation that supports automatic processing.  

This grant was awarded to members of the Spatial Ontology Community of Practice (SOCoP), a group committed to creating semantic interoperability for geospatial data. The intellectual merit in this project includes creating ontologies, helping develop the GeoSPARQL Semantic Web query language that contains spatial operators, and developing prototype software that will use ontologies and other semantic technologies for application needs. The work advances technology in the Semantic Web area and, in addition, enables a Geospatial Semantic Web.

Project activities included organizing workshops, including GeoVoCamps to create Ontology Design Patterns (ODPs), which are models for repeatable patterns. Our workshop and extensive outreach activities grew the Network of people interested in geospatial semantics, who are now working together. Our contacts were furthered through association with Ontolog, a world-wide group of those interested in ontologies, and we helped organize and participated in many virtual and in person Ontolog sessions. We also are actively involved with the new International Association for Ontology and its Applications, EarthCube, the Research Data Alliance, and the Earth Science Information Partners (ESIP).

 Other activities included implementing a graphical GeoQuery tool to make it easy to pose GeoSPARQL queries over the Web and display results on a map. We also developed and populated an instance of an Open Ontology Repository (OOR) to host geospatial ontologies, as part of a larger software repository effort to store and search re-useable ontologies. Other software was written to access mappings between land use codes that we merged from seven land use classification systems. Additional software created a Web-based demo to query our land use ontology. Other software developed Web services to remotely access an OOR instance to find ontology information. Also, work was done to suggest ways to integrate topics into the existing University Consortium of GIScience’s GIS and T Body of Knowledge to have geospatial semantics be integral to other basic GIScience knowledge. The images included here show some of our work (Trajectory ODP, GeoSPARQL, GeoQuery tool, SOCoP OOR, and Land Use ontology).

The broader impacts of the project include

  • creating a network of people working on semantic interoperability for geospatial data,
  • training students in the topic,
  • developing a new course in geospatial semantics as well as other talks and lectures,
  • and creating and guiding several undergraduate research projects.
